conclusion: Determine the speed of the block at point B and the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B.
The block is released from rest at point A, and potential energy at point A is converted into kinetic energy at point B.
The radius of the circular track is 0.8 m.
Height of A above B is calculated as 1.4 m.
Initial potential energy at A is mg times 1.4 m.
Kinetic energy at B is 0.5 mv^2.
Equating potential energy at A to kinetic energy at B gives g times 1.4 equals 0.5 v^2.
Solve for v gives v equals sqrt(28) approximately 5.29 m/s.
At point B, the block experiences centripetal force due to its motion along the circular path.
The gravitational force acting on the block is mg.
The supporting force (normal force) N provides the necessary centripetal force.
Net force towards the center of the circle is the centripetal force N - mg equals mv^2/r.
Solve for N gives N equals mg plus mv^2/r.
Substitute known values gives N equals mg plus 35m.
Calculate the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force gives N/mg equals 4.5.
The speed of the block when it slides from point A to point B is approximately 5.29 m/s.
The ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is 4.5.
